=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Summary of the Game:

• Genre and Theme:
 – It’s a classic 2D space shooter reminiscent of arcade games.
 – The setting is a space environment featuring a planet (the base), spaceships (the avatar), aliens, and incoming projectiles.

• Key Game Elements and Sprites:
 – Background and Base: The base (a planet image) is an immovable object that appears to be important—possibly a target to defend.
 – Player Avatar: A spaceship (labeled as “avatar”) that the player controls. It has a special “FlakAvatar” behavior, likely making it agile and able to shoot.
 – Projectiles: There are missiles (“missile”) and two bullet types—a friendly bullet (“sam”, which moves upward) and enemy bombs (“bomb”, moving downward slowly).
 – Enemies: Aliens appear in two visual types (alienBlue and alienGreen) that come from invisible portals. They have bomber behavior: they drop bombs towards the base.
 – Portals: Specialized spawn points that regularly generate alien enemies. There are two varieties—one with a longer cooldown (portalSlow) and one faster (portalFast).

• Mechanics and Interactions:
 – Movement: The avatar likely moves in a bounded space (with the “EOS” – edge of screen – interactions prompting it to step back), while aliens react to edges by turning around.
 – Shooting: The avatar fires “sam” bullets straight upward, which can interact with both the base and enemy entities.
 – Collisions: 
  • When a “sam” projectile hits the base, both are destroyed and the score increases (+1).
  • If an alien collides with a “sam” projectile, the alien is killed and the player gains extra points (+2).
  • Colliding with aliens or enemy bombs directly costs the player (score –1) and leads to the destruction of the involved sprite.
  • The base gets hit by bombs, which results in both the bomb and base being destroyed, suggesting that protecting the base might be crucial.

• Objective and Win/Loss Conditions:
 – Win Condition: The game is won when all alien threats are eliminated—that is, when there are no aliens or active portals left (as tracked by the MultiSpriteCounter).
 – Loss Condition: The game is lost if the player’s avatar is destroyed (when the avatar count reaches 0).

• Overall Strategy:
 1. Defense and Offense: Manage your avatar’s position so you can both take out enemies and avoid dangerous collisions. Since your score worsens if you crash into aliens or bombs, dodging enemy fire is key.
 2. Prioritize Threats: Focus on eliminating the alien waves quickly. Use your missiles (“sam” bullets) to take down aliens before they near your base or drop bombs.
 3. Protect the Base: Since collisions between bombs and the base lead to mutual destruction, keeping the base safe (if it’s a play objective or contributes to your overall performance) should be a priority.
 4. Positioning: Stay alert at the edges of the playing field; the avatar rebounds when touching the edge, so use boundaries to your advantage when evading or maneuvering.
 5. Timing Your Shots: Look for opportunities when aliens are vulnerable—especially note the interaction that rewards you (+2) when a “sam” bullet hits an alien. This suggests that careful, well-timed shooting can net you extra points.
 6. Observe Enemy Spawn Rates: As aliens come from portals with distinct cooldowns, plan your movements and shooting patterns around the expected enemy spawns to maintain control over the battle space.

In essence, the game is about balancing aggressive offense with careful evasion. Kill off enemies efficiently to clear out the portals and win while protecting your avatar (and possibly the base) from enemy counterattacks.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.
